Step 1: We admitted we were powerless
column2: over alcohol, that our lives had become unmanageable.

Acceptance: Step 2: Came to believe that a Power
column2: greater than ourselves could restore us to sanity.

Acceptance: Step 3: Made a decision to turn our will and our
column2: lives over to the care of God as we understood Him.
and fearless moral inventory of ourselves.

Acceptance: Step 5: Admitted to God, to ourselves, and to
column2: another human being the exact nature of our wrongs.

Acceptance: Step 6: Were entirely ready to have
column2: God remove all these defects of character.
Him to remove our shortcomings.

Acceptance: Step 8: Made a list of all persons we had
column2: harmed, and became willing to make amends to them all.

Acceptance: Step 9: Made direct amends to such people wherever possible,
column2: except when to do so would injure them or others.

Acceptance: Step 10: Continued to take personal inventory,
column2: and when we were wrong, promptly admitted it.

Acceptance: Step 11: Sought through prayer and meditation to improve our conscious contact with God as we understood
column2: Him, praying only for knowledge of His will for us and the power to carry that out.

Acceptance: Step 12: Having had a spiritual awakening as the result of these steps, we tried
column2: to carry this message to alcoholics, and to practice these principles in all our affairs.
